align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: center; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 14.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Constitution of <span style="mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">Bangladesh 1972<br/></span></span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Article 35(4)</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">— Notice given by DACO is not violative of article 35(4)—</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Anti-Corruption Act, 1957</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">—</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> Section 3</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">— Notice during preliminary enquiry—</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">A District Anti-Corruption officer is deemed to be an officer-in-charge of a police-station under section 3 of the Anti-Corruption Act, 1957 and as such he can very well exercise his powers under section 94 and 160 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. Giving notice by District Anti-Corruption officer to a person to give statement in preliminary enquiry which is of fact-finding nature at the stage when there is no criminal proceedings started against him, is not violative of the provision of article 35(4) of the Constitution. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Abdul Hafiz (Md) and others Vs. Director General, Bureau of Anti-Corruption and others</span></em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">— 3, MLR (1998) (HC) 130.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Article 35</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">—</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Anti-Corruption Act, 1957</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">— Section 4(1)— Notice calling for Statement of property— during preliminary enquiry—</span></strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">Not violative of fundamental rights-There is nothing wrong in the order passed in pursuance of the satisfaction of the Government directing to submit statement of property under section 4(1) of the Anti-Corruption Act and as such this does not offend fundamental right guaranteed under article 35(4) of the Constitution as the petitioners are not accused in any criminal case following FIR or complaint.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Mustafizur Rahman and others Vs. Director General, Bureau of Anti-Corruption</span></em><em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">— 4, </span></em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">MLR (1999) (HC) 138.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">Article 104— Inordinate Delay not condoned on plea of doing complete justice—</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">When the accused inspite of knowledge remained silent for 5 years after conviction, such inordinate delay cannot be condoned on the alleged ground of sickness and on the plea of doing complete justice.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">Md, Abdw Rahman Vs. The State</span></em><em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">— </span></em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">1, MLR (1996) (AD) 447.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">Article 102—Direction for release</span></strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> <strong><span style="color: black;">of person wrongly put behind the</span></strong> <strong><span style="color: black;">bar</span></strong></span><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">—</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">When an innocent wrong person is apprehended and put into jail to undergo imprisonment for life in place of the actual accused tried and convicted in absentia for murder charge, the High Court Division can rightly interfere and direct his release. The court expressed serious concern against the irresponsible and careless police officer connected therewith and directed payment of exemplary compensation to the innocent person so detained.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">Shahnewaz (Md) Vs. Government of Bangladesh represented by the</span></em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> <em><span style="color: black;">Secretary,<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>Ministry<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>of Home Affairs and others</span></em></span><em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">—3, </span></em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">MLR(1998) (HC) 54.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;"> </span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">Article 102-</span></strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> <strong><span style="color: black;">Public interest litigation in respect of safe custody / judicial custody of minor</span></strong></span><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">—</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">Penal Code- Section 364-Abduction of minor girl- custody of the victim girl</span></strong><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">—</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">Disputed question of facts does not come within the writ jurisdiction of High Court Division under article 102 of the Constitution. As the question of safe custody does not involve community interest, so a member of the Public who is not a person aggrieved has no locus standi and cannot invoke writ jurisdiction.</span><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> <span style="color: black;">Keeping a victim minor girl in 'safe custody/judicial custody has no express provision of law in support thereof but there are series of judicial decisions of our apex court which lay the strong legal basis of judicial custody of minor victim as a matter of long practice in our legal system.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">Rokeya Kabir (Mrs.) </span></em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">Vs. Government <em>of Bangladesh &amp; others- </em>5.MLR (2000) (HC) 58.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">Article 35—</span></strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;"> <strong>Preventive</strong></span><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> <strong><span style="color: black;">detention</span></strong></span><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">— Non-disclosure of grounds— Plea of public interest-Privileged document— court's power to look into— Principles of natural justice—</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">Freedom of movement of a citizen is a fundamental right guaranteed under the Constitution. Such right of a citizen can be curtailed only on sufficient grounds for preventing prejudicial acts. State has privilege not to disclose fact of any document in the interest of peace or public interest. But when liberty of a citizen is at stake' and when constitutional protection is sought for the constitutional court i.e. the High Court Division of the Supreme Court alone can look into such privileged document in order to be satisfied as to the propriety of the claim of the detaining authority. The detenu can not claim disclosure of such fact pertaining to his detention as a matter of right. Unless there is any such situation warranting privilege of non­disclosure of any such document 'in public interest withholding of such materials from being disclosed to the detenu will tantamount to violation of principle of natural justice and</span><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> <span style="color: black;">thereby rendering the detention denude of any legal authority. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">Habiba Mahmud Vs.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>Bangladesh-45 DLR (AD) 89.</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">Article 102—</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898</span></strong><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">—</span></strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> <strong><span style="color: black;">Section 439A</span></strong></span><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">— Revisional jurisdiction— Once exercised—second Revision or writ does not lie-</span></strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">Where procedural remedy is expressly provided for in any particular matter a litigant has no scope to invoke inherent power of the court. On the disposal of a revision under section 439A of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 by the Sessions Judge the matter ends there. Thereafter neither second revision nor writ lies on the self same matter.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">Haji Golam Hossain Vs. Abdar Rahman Munshi- 40 DLR (AD) 196.</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">Article 102</span></strong><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">— Interference in exercise of writ jurisdiction with conviction—</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">Permissible in case of trial held without jurisdiction</span></strong><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">—</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">High Court Division in exercise of writ jurisdiction can declare conviction of an accused in a trial held without jurisdiction as illegal.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">State Vs.</span></em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;"> <em>Zahir and others. 45 DIM. (AD) 163.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">Article 102</span></strong><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">—</span></strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> <strong><span style="color: black;">Interference with detention in exercise of writ jurisdiction</span></strong></span><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">— on ground of malafide and collateral purpose—</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">Bangladesh judicial view is different from that of Indian jurisdiction in approach with regard to subjective satisfaction in cases of preventive detention. To follow principles of Indian decisions in cases of preventive detention will be dangerous slip from the well established judicial view of Bangladesh jurisdiction.</span><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> <span style="color: black;">The validity of the order of detention, has to be tested on the basis of materials before the detaining authority which gave a rational probative value to the order and not based on extraneous purpose beyond the scope of the Act. When this test is satisfied the order is immune from challenge. But when the order is passed for collateral purpose and is malafide one it is illegal and is liable to be struck down.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">Sajeda Parvin Vs. Government of Bangladesh. 40 DLR (AD) 178.</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">Article 103</span></strong><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">— Scope of interference by Appellate Division with findings of fact on ground of serious defect—</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">Appellate Division can well come to its own finding upon re-assessment of evidence on record by reversing the finding of fact of the High Court Division on ground of serious defect.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">State Vs.</span></em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;"> <em>Abdus Sattar -  43 DLR (AD) 44.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">Article 102—Detention for prejudicial activities—Malicious detention— Compensatory cost may be awarded—</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">Since detention involves curtailment of fundamental rights of freedom of movement and speech guaranteed under the Constitution, the order thereof must be based on specific genuine grounds relating to prejudicial activities. Malicious detention has to be viewed with serious concern and in appropriate cases apart from declaring such order as illegal exemplary compensatory cost may be awarded to be paid by the State as a deterrent measure so that the State instrumentalities do not indulge in reckless and malafide detention of its citizen curtailing the valuable fundamental human rights.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">Bilkis Akter Hossain Vs. Bangladesh represented by the Secretary Ministry of Home Affairs &amp; others. 2, MLR(1997) (HC) 113.</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">Article 142— Indemnity (Repeal) Act 1996—</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">Procedure for amendment of the provision of the Constitution</span></strong><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">— Indemnity Ordinance, 1975— Whether became part of the Constitution by reason of its inclusion in the paragraph 3A and 18 of the Fourth Schedule requiring its amendment through the procedure under article 142 of the Constitution.</span></strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> <strong><span style="color: black;">Indemnity (Repeal) Act 1996</span></strong></span><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">— Whether a valid piece of legislation—</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">Since the Constitution remained suspended during the Martial Law Regime the inclusion of all the Martial Law Regulations, Orders, Ordinance etc. in the Fourth Schedule of the Constitution after their ratification by the Parliament on the lifting of the</span><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> <span style="color: black;">Martial Law was for the purpose of maintaining continuity of the constitutional process. By reason of such inclusion the Indemnity Ordinance 1975 was never made part of the Constitution and as such this Ordinance could well be amended by the Parliament by simple majority just like ordinary legislation in which case article 142 of the Constitution is not applicable. Thus the Indemnity (Repeal) Act, 1996 is perfectly a valid law.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">Shohriar <span style="mso-bidi-font-style: italic;">Rashid Khan and another Vs. Bangladesh and others. 3,MLR (1998) (AD) 233.</span></span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; color: black;">Article 142—</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">In</span></strong><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">demnity Repeal Act, 1996 (Act No.21 of 1996)</span></strong><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">—</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Whether ultra vires the Constitution</span></strong><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">—</span></strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> <strong>Indemnity Ordinance, 1975</strong></span><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">— Paragraph 3A and 18 of the 4th Schedule of the Constitution— Inclusion in the schedule does not form part of the Constitution—­An </span></strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">Ordinance though protected by way of inclusion in the schedule of the Constitution does not form part of the Constitution. The Indemnity Ordinance, 1975 (Ord 50 of 1975) as </span><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">such not being part of the Constitution does not require two third majority members of the Parliament for its repeal as contemplated by article 142 of the Constitution. When Constitution provides equality of every citizen before law, the Indemnity Ordinance 1975 was violative of the basic principle and fundamental rights guaranteed under the Constitution and as such the Indemnity Ordinance, 1975 being a simple legislation has been rightly and validly repealed by the Indemnity (Repeal) Act 1996 (Act No 21 of 1996) by simple majority members of the Parliament. The Indemnity (Repeal) Act, 1996 being a valid legislation is not <em>ultra vires </em>the Constitution and as such is not liable to be struck down. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Shahriar Rashid Khan and Mrs. Mahmuda Raliman Vs. Bangladesh represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Law and others- 2, MLR (1997) (HC) 25.</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Article 102</span></strong><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">— The Special Powers Act,<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>1974—</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Section <span style="mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">30- Provisions for appeal-</span></span></strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Where the<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>alternative<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>remedy<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>is available<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>under<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>section<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">   </span>30<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>of the Special Powers Act, 1974 normally the writ jurisdiction under article 102 of the Constitution can not be invoked. But when in view of unusual circumstance the convict-appellant was deprived of his legal right of defence and the trial held beyond his knowledge and due to lack of knowledge he could not avail of the 'remedy under section 30 of the Special Powers Act, the extra-ordinary jurisdiction of the High Court Division under article 102 of the Constitution can well be invoked with a view to preventing the miscarriage of justice. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Mobarak All (Md) alias Mobarak Ali Mondal Vs. Bangladesh represented by Secretary Ministry of Home Affairs and others. 4, MLR (1999) (HC) 13.</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Natural Justice</span></strong><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">—</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Natural justice means no person should be condemned unheard and without giving opportunity of defence</span><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">— 4, MLR (1999) (AD) 10.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Show cause notice</span></strong><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">—</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Show cause notice is not a mere technicality or idle ceremony, Show cause notice must not be vague. When it is vague, it is not a show cause notice in the eye of law</span><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">—4, MLR (1999) (AD) 9.</span></p><p> </p></div></div>

<w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="62" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light Grid Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="63" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Shading 1 Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="64" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Shading 2 Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="70" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Dark List Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="71" SemiHidden="false" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"> </span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: center; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-size: 14.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: black;">Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1958</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Section 6(5)-Sanction for prosecution</span></strong><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">—Duty of Special Judge—</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Whether a public servant should be prosecuted or not is entirely within the jurisdiction of the Government. Sanction of the Government is a pre­condition for the prosecution of a public servant. Special judge has to write to the Government for sanction upon receipt of a complaint or a police report not accompanied with sanction before any step is taken. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Abdur Rahim @ Md Abdur Rahim Vs. The State</span></em><em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">—1, </span></em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">MLR (1996) (AD) 315.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">The Criminal Law Amendment (Amendment) Act 1987 (XIII of 1987)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Section 8 (a) - Section 339C of Cr.p.c- Time schedule for trial-Enforceability of</span></strong><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">—</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Proceeding of a special case can not be stopped under section 8 (a) of Act XIII of 1987 after the expiry of two years from 20-1-1987 the date of its coining into force when trial of the case did not commence or 270 working days did not expire after framing of the charge and before coming into force of the said Act.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Mojibul Haque Vs. The State</span></em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">— 1, MLR (1996) (HC) 33.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Section</span></strong><span style="font-family: 'Arial','sans-serif'; mso-hansi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"><span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span></span><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">5(1)</span></strong><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">—</span></strong> <strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-hansi-font-family: Arial;">Offences</span></strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> <strong>exclusively triable by Special Judge.</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Offences shown in paragraphs (b) and (c) of the schedule of the Act are triable by the Special Judge.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Mohor RanjanPal and others Vs. The State-2, </span></em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">MLRU997) (HC) 391.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Section 6(5)</span></strong><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">— Sanction is precondition- Not necessary where offence committed prior to his appointment as public servant—</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Sanction of the Government for prosecution of a public servant is a pre-condition without which trial of a public servant is illegal and of no legal effect. Sanction for prosecution of a public servant is not necessary in respect of offence committed prior to his appointment as public servant. Evidence recorded by Magistrate during erroneous trial cannot be used by the Special Judge in fresh trial. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Azam Shah Alamgir and others Vs. The State</span></em><em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">—2, </span></em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">MLR(1997) (HC) 391.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Section 6(5)</span></strong><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">— Sanction of the Government for prosecution— Prerequisite—</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Special Judge must write to the Government for sanction for prosecution of a Government servant upon receipt of the complaint before passing any order thereon. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Tarani Mohon Ghosh and others Vs. The State and another</span></em><em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">— 3, </span></em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">MLR (1998) (HC) 97.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Section 8</span></strong><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">— conviction after expiry of time limit—</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">When the trial could not be concluded within the time limit, there was, in fact, no proceeding after the expiry of the period. Trial held and conviction given after the expiry of the time limit is illegal. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">The <em>State Vs. Md. Minhazuddin Khan</em></span><em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">— </span></em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">4, MLR (1999) (AD) 147</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Sectioa<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">   </span>494</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">—<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>Withdrawal<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">   </span><span style="mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">from</span></span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> <span style="mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">prosecution</span></span></strong><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">— </span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"> </span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Section 10(4)- Withdrawal from prosecution-Role of the Special Judge</span></strong><strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">—</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Both section 494 of the Code of Criminal Procedure and section 10(4) of the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1958 shall have to be read together while allowing or refusing withdrawal from the prosecution. Special Judge is required to exercise this power judicially upon consideration of the materials on record. He should not record withdrawal from prosecution mechanically or as a matter of course simply on the filing of an application therefor. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Sreemoti Prativa Rani Dey (Tirtha) VS. Dr. Mohd. Yousuf and others</span></em><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">— 5, MLR <em>(2000) (AD) 33.</em></span></p><p> </p></div></div>
2961	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Cruelty to Women (Deterrent Punishment) Ordinance, 1983</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p></p><p style='margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;Cambria","serif";'><br/><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Crueltyto Women (Deterrent Punishment) Ordinance, 1983</span></b></p><p style='margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;Cambria","serif";'> </p><p style='margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;Cambria","serif";'>Section 4C of the Schedule - Whencharge is proved beyond all reasonable doubt <b><span style='Calibri","sans-serif";'>-</span></b><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b><b><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>Convictionand sentence upheld.</span></b></p><p style='margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;Cambria","serif";'>Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898</p><p style='margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;Cambria","serif";'>Section 339D - Revival of theproceedings not illegal - Minor discrepancies in evidence to be ignored. Contradictionof evidence is fatal for the prosecution.<span style='Cambria","serif";'><br/>When charge is well established by cogent and reliable evidence the convictionand sentence based thereon are held perfectly justified.</span></p><p style='margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph;Cambria","serif";'>Sree Nipu @ Nipen Chandra Vs. TheState ii MLR <span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>(2006)<i>(HC) 360. </i></span></p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span> </div></div>
2962	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Customs Act, 1969</h2>

style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 14pt; color: black;">Drugs (Control) Ordinance, 1982</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;"> </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Code of Criminal Procedure 1898</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Section 339B— Trial in absentia—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Drugs (Control) Ordinance, 1982</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Section 16A, 16B and 20—</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">Limitation of appeal immaterial when court lacks in jurisdiction</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;">Publication of proclamation in Gazette and in two daily Bengali Newspapers is a mandatory pre­condition k f absentia trial as provided under section 339B of the Code of Criminal Procedure 1898. When such publication is not made, the court can not try the accused in his absence. Limitation of appeal is not material when the court lacks in jurisdiction.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Nazral Islam Chowdhury Vs. The State</span></em><em><span style="color: black;">— </span></em><span style="color: black;">4, MLR (1999) (AD) 221.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;"> </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Drug court- additional forum-</span></strong> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">The Special Powers Act, 1974</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Section 25C(d)—Proceedings can not be quashed u/s 561A Cr.P.C.— When drawn under proper law and in proper forum—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">The Drug Court constituted under the Drugs (Control) Ordinance, 1982 is an additional forum for trying drug offences. The taking of cognizance and framing charge for drug offences by the Special Tribunal for possession of spurious medicines are not illegal and as such the proceedings are not liable to be quashed under section 561A of the Code of Criminal Procedure.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Ashraf @ Ashrqf Ali Vs. The State</span></em><em><span style="color: black;">— </span></em><span style="color: black;">2, MLR(1997) (AD) 35.</span></span></p><p> </p></div></div>

align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: center; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 14pt; color: black;">Family Courts Ordinance, 1985</span></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: center; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 14pt; font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 5 and Section 23</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Jurisdiction— Applicable to all citizens  irrespective of religion— Jurisdiction of Magistrate us 488 Cr.P.C. barred—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">The Family Courts Ordinance, 1985 is a self contained law which provides special forum for speedy disposal of disputes enumerated in section 5. Simply for the use of the words "subject to the provision of the Muslim Family Laws Ordinance, 1961" in section 5, the Family Courts Ordinance is not meant for the members of the Muslim Community only. The Family Courts Ordinance is applicable to all the citizens of Bangladesh irrespective of their faith or religion. The Family Court while deciding the dispute shall follow the personal laws of the respective parties. The Family court has exclusive jurisdiction in matters of maintenance of wife and children and as such after the coming into force of the Family Courts Ordinance 1985, no Magistrate can now entertain any application or initiate any proceeding under section 488 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Pochon Rikssi Das Vs. Khaku  Rani Dasi and others.</span></em> <em><span style="color: black;">3, MLR (1998)</span></em> <em><span style="color: black;">(HC) 145.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 16 (3B)— Imprisonment of the judgmentdebtor for failure to pay the instalment of decretal money— Legal position in case of repeated failure—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">The Family Courts Ordinance, 1985 is a special law for effectively dealing</span> <span style="color: black;">with certain family matters. Section 16(3B) of the Ordinance provides for putting the judgment-debtor into imprisonment for three months for failure to pay decretal money. When the Court allowed instalments of the decretal amount to be paid on his own seeking of the judgment-debtor, he is bound to pay the same. In case of failure of payment of decretal money the judgment-debtor is liable to suffer imprisonment for default of each instalment.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Maksuda Akhter  Vs.  Md.   Serajul Islam. 5 MLR (2000)(HC) 276.</span></em></span></p></div></div>

1860</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—Section 406 and 420— Immigration Ordinance, 1982—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 23 and 26</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Joint trial— Not permissible—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Joint trial of offences under section 406 and 420 of the Penal Code and of section 23 of Immigration Ordinance 1982 by the Special Court is not permissible as the offence under section 23 of the Immigration Ordinance, 1982 is exclusively triable by Special Court while the offence under section 406 and 420 of the Penal Code are triable by the Magistrate. Where ingredients of the offences under section 406 and 420 of the Penal Code and under section 23 of the Immigration Ordinance, are contained in the allegation, prosecution in both the courts for the respective offences are competent.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Mosammat Noor Jahan Begum @ Anchuri &amp; another Vs. The Stale</span></em><span style="color: black;">— 2, MLR(1997) (AD) 34.</span></span></p></div></div>

<w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="39" QFormat="true" Name="TOC Heading"/> </w:LatentStyles></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 10]><style> /* Style Definitions */
