align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: center; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 14pt; color: black;">The Special Powers Act, 1974</span></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: center; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12pt; color: black;"> (XIV of 1974)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;"> </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">The Special Powers Act, 1974</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Section 3(2)- Grounds of detention—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">It is obligatory on the part of the detaining authority to show by affidavit-in opposition that the detenu is not held in custody without lawful authority or in unlawful manner except when the cause or manner is adequately explained in the writ petition in which case the respondent can reply on the materials on record to justify the detention or continued detention otherwise the order of dentention will fall for lack of cause shown. <em>Nasima Begum Vs. Government o Bangladesh-----</em></span><span style="font-size: 12pt; color: black;">1, MLR (1996) (AD) 129.</span></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: center; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Customs Act, 1969, Section 25B- Smuggling of cattle heads</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Although not defined in the category of goods include Special Powers Adt, the term goods include cattle and as such the offence of bringing" cattle' into Bangladesh without proper authority is triable by the Special Tribunal under the Special Powers Act.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Suruj Al Mamun Sukur Ali Vs. The State</span></em><em><span style="color: black;">— </span></em><span style="color: black;">1, MLR (1996) (AD) 291.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Code   of   Criminal   Procedure, </strong><strong>1898, </strong> <strong>Section 561A—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Special Powers Act, 1974</strong><strong>—</strong> <strong>Section 27</strong><strong>—</strong><strong>Quashment of proceedings</strong><strong>—Not</strong> <strong>permissible</strong><strong>—No wrong in sending complaint after examination of complaint under section 20Q to police for investigation under</strong> <strong>section  27  of the  Special Powers Act, 1974</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">There is nothing wrong in sending the complaint to the police for investigation after examination of the complainant under section 200 of the Code of Criminal Procedure where cognizance can not be taken except upon a police report as required by section 27 of the Sp[ecial powers Act, 1974. It is not correct  that only the Magistrate competent to take cognizance can send such complaint to the police for investigation.  </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em>Golam Rahman Vs. The State </em><em>and another</em><em>—</em>5, MLR(2000) (HC);239.  </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section 27-FRT</strong><strong>— Discharge by Maigistrate- Cognizance by Special Tribunal—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">Magistrate has the jurisdiction discharge an accused on the basis of police report exclusively triable by Special Tribunal. Under Section 27 Special Tribunal has been given discretion to take cognizance on the basis of police report against an accussed discharged by the Magistrate. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em>Narayan Chandra </em><em>Das Vs. The State and others </em>MLR (1996) (HC) 267.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em> </em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Special Powers Act. 1974 (Act </strong><strong>XIV of 1974</strong>)</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section 5(3)- detention-extension of</strong><strong>—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">The order of detention passed by the District Magistrate/Additional District Magistrate under section 3(2) for more than 30 days is not valid unless in the meantime it; has been approved by the Government u/s 3(3) of the Act.  Government has no power to extend <span style="color: black;">the detention ordered by the District Magistrate / Additional District Magistrate. The Government has power u/s 3(1) to order detention for unlimited period which is subject to sections 10, 11 and provisio to section 12 of the Act.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;"> </span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Yeasmin Akhtar Vs. the State</span></em><span style="color: black;">— 1. MLR (1996) (HC) 14.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 3(l)(a) and 3(2)— Government can not extend detention given by the Magistrate—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">District Magistrate/Additional District Magistrate is authorised under section 3(2) to issue an order of detention of a detenu for a period not exceeding 30 days which need no approval of the Government. On the other hand the Government under section 3(1)(a) can direct detention independently but it cannot extend the detention granted by the District/Additional District Magistrate under section 3(2).</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">S.M. Feroz Vs. Government of Bangladesh represented by the Secretary Ministry of Home Affairs and others </span></em><em><span style="color: black;">—2, </span></em><span style="color: black;">MLR(1997) (HC) 334.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section </span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">3(2)—Detention on grounds of prejudicial acts—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Detention cannot be sustainable in law unless the grounds therefor</span> <span style="color: black;">strictly conform to the ingredients of prejudicial acts within the meaning of section 3(2) of the Special Powers Act, 1974.</span> <span style="color: black;">Freedom of expression and movement, the valuable fundamental rights cannot be throatled and curtailed by colourable exercise of the authority under the Special Powers Act in a democratic polity. When specific case is started under relevant law the sword of damocles i.e. the detention cannot be resorted to.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Halima Farzana Vs. Government of the Peoples Republic of Bangladesh and others - 4 MLR (1999) (HC) 255.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 2(f)- defines prejudicial acts</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 3(l)(a)- Order of preventive detention can only be made when any of the grounds as defined under section 2(f) exists and not otherwise</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Liberty of movement is an important fundamental right of a citizen guaranteed under the Constitution which can not be curtailed except in accordance with law. When there is no ground that a person is about to engage himself in prejudicial acts which may endanger public order and public safety the Government can not make preventive order to be kept him in detention. No person can be detained on the ground that some other persons are likely to endanger public safety and maintenance of public order. Satisfaction of the Government as to the grounds must be based on genuine materials and must not be subjective satisfaction.</span> <span style="color: black;">Executive action in relation to preventive detention is not immune from judicial review by the Supreme Court. When the order of detention does not conform strictly to the requirements of law it is liable to be struck down.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Mustafizur Rahman vs. Bangladesh represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs-</span></em><span style="color: black;">3, MLR (1998). (AD) 169,</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif; color: black;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Constitution of Bangladesh— Article</span></strong> <strong><span style="color: black;">35—</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">Preventive</span></strong> <strong><span style="color: black;">detention</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Non-disclosure of grounds— Plea of public interest-Privileged document— court's power to look into— Principles of natural justice—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Freedom of movement of a citizen is a fundamental right guaranteed under the Constitution. Such right of a citizen can be curtailed only on sufficient grounds for preventing prejudicial acts. State has privilege not to disclose fact of any document in the interest of peace or public interest.</span> <span style="color: black;">But when liberty of a citizen is at stake and when constitutional protection is sought for the constitutional court i.e. the High Court Division of the Supreme Court alone can look into such privileged document in order to be satisfied as to the propriety of the claim of the detaining authority. The detenu can not claim disclosure of such fact pertaining to his detention as a matter of right. Unless there is any such situation warranting privilege of non­disclosure of any such document in public interest withholding of such materials from being disclosed to the detenu will tantamount to violation of principle of natural justice and thereby rendering the detention denude of any legal authority.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Habiba Mahmud Vs. Bangladesh-45. DLR (AD) 89.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Constitution of Bangladesh</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Article   102—  Interference   with detention    in    exercise    of   writ jurisdiction— on ground of malafide and collateral purpose—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Bangladesh judicial view is different from that of Indian jurisdiction in approach with regard to subjective satisfaction in cases of preventive detention. To follow principles of Indian decisions in cases of preventive detention will be dangerous slip from</span> the well established judicial view of Bangladesh jurisdiction.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">The validity of the order of detention has to be tested on the basis of materials before the detaining authority which gave a rational probative Value to the order and not based on extraneous purpose beyond the scope of the Act- When this test is satisfied the order' is immune from challenge. But when the order is passed f6r collateral purpose and is malafide one it is illegal and is liable to be struck down. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em>Sajeda Parvin  Vs.   Government of</em> <em>Bangladesh. 40 DLR (AD) 178.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em> </em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong> </strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section 25B(1) and 25D—</strong> <strong>Reducing  the  sentence on</strong> <strong>compassionate ground</strong><strong>—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">When the accused frankly confessed their guilt and made clean breast of their offence from the very beginning and never tried to beat the law and always begged mercy of the Court, although the High Court Division rightly, exercised its discretion in reducing the sentence of imprisonment for life to 14 years Rigorous imprisonment, yet the Appellate Division being impressed by the Sad plight of the two<sup>1</sup>fidreigrier' cdrivictmppellarits in alien with different life style, food habit and language in complete mcomtriuBicado, is pleased to further reduce their sentence to 7 years following the doctrine to administer justice tempered with mercy. Further It is held that punishrnent of the abettor cannot be higher than that of the principal accused and accordingly the sentence of convict appellant Ashrafuddin Sekander is also reduced to seven years rigorous imprisonment. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em>Ashrafuddin Sekander (Major Reid) and others vs. The State </em>3,MLR(1998) (AD)   164.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong> </strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section 30</strong><strong>—</strong> <strong>Provision of appeal</strong><strong>—Alteration of sentence into one of non-schedule offence- not permissible—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">Section 30 of the Special Powers Act, 1974 provides for appeal against the judgment and .order of the Special Tribunal. In an appeal under section 30, the High Court Division can not alter the conviction and sentence passed by Special Tribunal under section 376 into one under section 342 of the Penal Code which is not triable by the Special Tribunal under the Special Powers Act. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em>Abdur Rahman and others. The </em>State—4. MLR (1999) (AD)25.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section 25B— Grant of bail with unusual</strong>  <strong>conditions-  Not</strong> <strong>approved--</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">Unusual conditions as to the sureties of bail Should not be imposed. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em>Abdul Latif Vs The State 5, </em>MLR (HC) 360.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section 25B(2)— Punishment for offence of dealing in contrabands—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">Unless the prosecution shows by law/notification that certain articles are contrabands and have been smuggled <em>' </em>into Bangladesh in ctititraventiori of certain law, no conviction for dealing in such alleged cdritfabands simply by verbal assertion, can ridt be sustainable. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em>Jamiruddin Vs The State</em><em>— </em>5; MLR(2000)(HC) 385.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em> </em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>The Explosives Substance Act 1908—Section 3—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>The Special Powers Act, 1974</strong><strong>—Absentia trial-Remedy when  riot  appealed <span style="font-variant: small-caps;">fifth</span>—</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">An absconding accused may be tried in his absence after publication of proclamation in two daily news papers. Where the case is triable by Special Tribunal publication should be made by the Tribunal and not by Magistrate. Under section 340 of the Code of Criminal Pn£ced Ure an accused lacing capital' charge even if absconding is entitled to state defence. When not provided with state defence the trial is vitiated. Merely because the convict-appellant failed to avail of the provision of appeal under section 30 of the Special Powers Act 1974 an application under article 102 of the Constitution is not barred. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em>Senta Vs. Government of Bangadesh and others</em><em>— </em>MLR(1998HHC) 271.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Section 3(l)(a)—  Detention on ground of serious allegations— when Criminal case is pending</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;">If the detaining authority is satisfied that the detenu might indulge in prejudicial activities and there are serious allegations against him, order of his detention may be made in Order to prevent him from indulging in prejudicial activities even when there is criminal case pending against him; </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em>Jabitia Mahmud </em>Vs. <em>'Bangladesh -</em> <em>45 DLR (AD) 89.</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong>Article 102</strong><strong>— Detection for prejudicial activities-Malicious detention Compensatory cost may be awarded</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Since detention involves curtailment of fundamental rights of freedom of movement and speech guaranteed under the Constitution, the order thereof must be based on specific genuine grounds relating to prejudicial activities. Malicious detention has to be viewed with serious concern and in appropriate cases apart from declaring such order as illegal exemplary compensatory cost may be awarded to be paid by the State as a deterrent measure so that the State instrumentalities do not indulge in reckless and malafide detention of its citizen curtailing the valuable fundamental human rights.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Bilkis Akter Hossain Vs. Bangladesh represented by the Secretary Ministry of Home Affairs </span></em><span style="color: black;">&amp; others. <em>2, MLR(1997) (HC) 113.</em></span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 30— Provisions for appeal-</span></strong><span style="color: black;">Where the alternative remedy is available under section 30 of the Special Powers Act, 1974 normally the writ jurisdiction under article 102 of the Constitution can not be invoked. But when in view of unusual circumstance the convict-appellant was deprived of his legal right of defence and the trial held beyond his knowledge and due to lack of</span> <span style="color: black;">knowledge he could not avail of the remedy under section 30 of the Special Powers Act, the extra-ordinary jurisdiction of the High Court Division under article 102 of the Constitution can well be invoked with a view to preventing the miscarriage of justice.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><em><span style="color: black;">Mobarak All (Md) alias Mobarak Ali Mondal Vs. Bangladesh represented by Secretary Ministry of Home Affairs and others. 4, MLR (1999) (HC) 13.</span></em></span></p><p> </p></div></div>

align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: center; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 14pt; color: black;">Village Courts Ordinance,   1976 </span></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: center; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12pt; color: black;">(LXI of 1976)</span></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: center; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Section 3</span></strong><strong><span style="color: black;">— Jurisdiction- of Village Court and Magistrate Hearing of appeal by the Sessions Judge coram non Judice—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">All cases relating to offences specified in Part I of the Schedule to the Ordinance shall be exclusively triable by a village Court and not by any criminal Court. Trial of the accused for offences falling under the schedule by the Magistrate and hearing of the appeal by the Sessions Judge are absolutely without jurisdiction. If a court has no jurisdiction to try a case, the question of either submitting to the jurisdiction or raising objection to its jurisdiction would not arise. Parties by their mutual consent can neither confer a jurisdiction which does not exist in law nor can take away a jurisdiction which so exists. Jurisdiction is a question of statute and not of consent.</span> <em><span style="color: black;">Dr. Joynal Abedin Vs. State- 44 DLR (AD) 77. </span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><strong><span style="color: black;">Penal Code  1860— Section 427, 506 II— Offence triable by Magistrate and not by village court—</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph; line-height: normal; background: white; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: verdana,geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="color: black;">Where in a case an offence triable by the village court is joined with the offence triable by the Magistrate, the case shall be triable by the Magistrate and not by the village Court.</span> <em><span style="color: black;">Abul Kalam and others Vs. Abu Daud Gazi and another</span></em><em><span style="color: black;">— </span></em><span style="color: black;">4, MLR (1999) (AD) 414.</span></span></p></div></div>
